are much better compared to the PEG-b-PPG-b-PEG modified graphene oxide (GO–P).[57] When used as a photothermal nanoagent, the Ta2NiS5–P showed good efficacy for killing HeLa cells due to its good photothermal properties. Specifically, after incubation with Ta2NiS5–P (0.1 mg mL−1), most of HeLa cells (≈90%) were killed after laser irradiation with the power density of 1.0 W cm−2 for 8 min. More importantly, owing to the strong absorption in NIR region, the Ta2NiS5–P can effectively emit PA signals in the wavelength range of 675–950 nm. By combining the good photothermal properties and PA imaging, the Ta2NiS5–P was also used as an efficient nanoagent for passively target, effectively delineate, and completely eradicate the tumor of living mice after systemic administration (Figure 13e).[57]

sections.heading: 4.5. Energy Storage and Conversion
sections.text:
Due to the earth abundance of transition metal elements and tunable properties originating from their multiple chemical compositions, ultrathin 2D multinary layered metal chalcogenide nanomaterials also showed great potential in energy storage and conversion. For example, Xie and co-workers reported that the exfoliated hydrogenated-Cu2WS4 nanosheet can be used to as the electrode to fabricate high-performance all-solid-state flexible supercapacitors.[45] It was found that the hydrogenated-Cu2WS4 nanosheet exhibited excellent conductivity up to 2.9 × 104 S m−1, which is 1010 higher than that of the semiconducting bulk Cu2WS4 crystal. Specifically, the gold-coated PET substrate covered with the hydrogenatedCu2WS4 nanosheet film was used as the working electrode, and the polyvinyl alcohol (PVA)–LiCl gel was used as solid-state polymer electrolyte. Importantly, the hydrogenated-Cu2WS4 nanosheet-based all-solid-state supercapacitor showed high specific capacitance of 583.3 F cm−3 at a current density of 0.31 A cm−3 (Figure 14a–c).[45] The energy density at the same current density is estimated to be 0.029 Wh cm−3, giving a power density of 0.187 W cm−3. Furthermore, the hydrogenated-Cu2WS4 nanosheet based-supercapacitor exhibited excellent flexibility without obvious degradation in capacitance even after 500 bending–extending cycles, indicating its great potential for future portable energy storage devices. In another example, our group demonstrated that the CuSTiS2 vertical heteronanostructure could be used as the anode in a LIB cell, which showed a high capacity and good cycling stability.[148] Specifically, the discharge capacity of 626 mAhg−1 and charge capacity of 578 mAhg−1 were recorded on the CuSTiS2 heteronanostructure-based electrode during the second cycle, which is much higher than that of pure CuS nanosheet and TiS2. This CuSTiS2 heteronanostructure-based electrode still remained capacities of 350 and 260 mAhg−1 at high current densities of 3 and 6 Ag−1, respectively, indicating its excellent rate-cycling performance. Interestingly, our group recently demonstrated that single-layer MoS2xSe2(1−x) nanosheet with ≈66% metallic 1T phase could be used as a highly efficient and cost-effective CE in a DSSC (Figure 14d).[105] The MoS2xSe2(1−x) nanosheet was coated on a fluorine-doped tin oxide (FTO) (FTO-exfoliated–MoS2xSe2(1−x)) by a simple drop-casting method. Importantly, the DSSC device using FTO-exfoliated–MoS2xSe2(1−x) as the CE gave a PCE of 6.5%, which is much higher than that of the annealed 2H MoS2xSe2(1−x) nanosheet-based CE

This may give the common guideline for the design of a new class of alternative CEs to replace Pt-based CEs in DSSCs.

sections.heading: 5. Conclusion and Outlooks
sections.text:
In summary, we have reviewed the latest research progress on the synthesis, characterization and applications of a newly emerging class of ultrathin 2D nanomaterials, i.e., multinary layered metal chalcogenide nanomaterials. Based on their atom arrangements, these ultrathin 2D multinary layered metal chalcogenide nanomaterials could be clarified as four typical types, including ternary metal chalcogenide with welldefined crystal structures, alloyed TMDs, heteroatom-doped TMDs, and 2D metal chalcogenide heteronanostructures. A variety of methods have been developed for preparation of ultrathin 2D multinary layered metal chalcogenide nanomaterials. Among these methods, the CVD method is the most widely used one for the controlled synthesis of alloyed TMDs, heteroatom-doped TMDs and 2D heteronanostructures. Various characterization techniques, particularly the HAADF– STEM imaging technique, have been used to characterize the prepared multi nary layered metal chalcogenide nanomaterials to clearly visualize their size, thickness, compositions, crystal phase, interface, and atom arrangements. Owing to their advantages compared to binary 2D TMD nanosheets, these 2D multinary layered metal chalcogenide nanomaterials exhibited enhanced performance in a number of applications, including electronics/optoelectronics (e.g., FETs and photodiodes), catalysis (e.g., HER), sensors (e.g., DNA detection), biomedicine (e.g., photothermal therapy) and energy storage and conversion (e.g., supercapacitor).
Given the short research history on ultrathin 2D multinary layered metal chalcogenide nanomaterials, there are still some challenges remaining in this field. On the one hand, most of ultrathin 2D multinary layered metal chalcogenide nanomaterials have been synthesized by the CVD or CVT combined with exfoliation. As known, both the CVD and CVT methods need high temperature and high vacuum, resulting in the high cost of synthesis process. Given that solution-based synthetic methods allow for the high-yield and large-scale synthesis of 2D nanomaterials in solution phase, one of the major challenges in this field is to develop effective wet-chemical synthesis methods for the high-yield and large-scale preparation of ultrathin 2D multinary layered metal chalcogenide nanomaterials in solution at relatively low cost. On the other hand, although the proof-of-concept applications of as-prepared ultrathin 2D multinary layered metal chalcogenide nanomaterials have been demon strated, the performance is highly dependent on their
size, shape, thickness, crystal phase, interface and doping effect. However the correlated relationship between structural characteristics and a specific application of ultrathin 2D multinary layered metal chalcogenide nanomaterials is still not clear. Therefore, understanding the strong correlated relationship is of great importance for further guiding the rational design and synthesis of ultrathin 2D multinary layered metal chalcogenide nanomaterials with desirable structural characteristics for given applications to achieve enhanced or optimal performance.
Given that the research on ultrathin 2D multinary layered metal chalcogenide nanomaterials only started a few years ago, lots of work can be done in the near future. On the one hand, currently, most of the research work mainly focus on limited types of ultrathin 2D multinary layered metal chalcogenide nanomaterials, such as Ta2NiS5, Ta2NiSe5 and Cu2WS4 (ternary metal chalcogenides), MoS2xS2(1−x) and MoxW1−xS2 (alloyed TMDs), heteroatom-doped MoS2, and 2D heteronanostructures among MoS2, WS2, MoSe2 and WSe2. Some new ultrathin 2D multinary metal chalcogenide nanomaterials, for example, new ternary metal chalcogenides (CoIn2S4 and Cu2MoS4), alloyed TMDs (TaS2xS2(1−x), TiS2xS2(1−x) and TixTa1−xS2), heteroatomdoped TMDs (heteroatom-doped WS2, MoSe2 or WSe2), and 2D heteronanostructures of ZrS2–ReS2, could also be synthesized by the well-developed or newly developed methods. Therefore, one of the future directions lies in preparation of novel ultrathin 2D multinary metal chalcogenide nanomaterials. On the other hand, these ultrathin 2D multinary layered metal chalcogenide nanomaterials have only been explored in several kinds of potential applications, including electronics/ optoelectronics, catalysis, sensors, biomedicine and energy storage and conversion. They might also be used for some new promising applications, such as electrocatalytic CO2 reduction, Na–ion batteries and water remediation. For example, the Cu2WS4 nanosheet might be used as a promising electrode material for Na–ion batteries, due to its high electrical conductivity and 2D structural characteristics. 2D alloyed TMDs of MoS2xS2(1−x) and MoxW1−xS2 might display enhanced performance for the electrocatalytic CO2 reduction compared to the pure MoS2 nanosheets. As a consequence, another promising future direction lies in the exploration of new potential applications of these ultrathin 2D multinary metal chalcogenide nanomaterials.

Nowadays, many ultrathin 2D multinary layered metal chalcogenide nanomaterials have been successfully prepared, which include ternary metal chalcogenides with well-defined crystal structures (e.g., Ta2NiS5 and Cu2WS4), alloyed TMD nanosheets (e.g., MoS2xSe2(1−x) and MoxW1−xS2), heteroatom-doped TMD nanosheets (e.g., Re-, Co-, V-, Cr-, or Ptdoped MoS2), and lateral or vertical metal chalcogenide heteronanostructures (e.g., MoS2–MoSe2 and MoS2–WS2). These 2D multinary layered metal chalcogenide nanomaterials can be prepared by those well-developed methods used for preparation of 2D TMDs, such as the chemical vapor deposition (CVD) and wet-chemical syntheses. In some cases, combining two different well-developed methods, e.g., chemical vapor transport (CVT) and mechanical exfoliation, is required to achieve the preparation of 2D multinary layered metal chalcogenide nanomaterials. It is worth pointing out that these ultrathin 2D multinary layered metal chalcogenide nanomaterials showed some unique advantages compared to 2D binary TMDs, rendering them to be fundamentally and technologically important in wide applications, including electronics/optoelectronics, catalysis, sensors, biomedicine and energy storage and conversion. Here, the aim is to give a comprehensive summary of the latest research progress in ultrathin 2D multinary layered metal chalcogenide nanomaterials. The classification and advantages of 2D multinary layered metal chalcogenide nanomaterials are first discussed, followed by the description of their preparation and characterization. Then, the great potential of these 2D multinary layered metal chalcogenide nanomaterials in various applications is introduced, such as electronics/optoelectronics, catalysis, sensors, biomedicine and energy storage and conversion. Finally, this review is concluded with some personal discussion on the challenges and outlooks in this rapidly emerging research area on the basis of the current research achievement.
